item.title: Need to Weave the Stories Together
item.dc:creator: anderbill
item.description:
Tony and Gene, I agree that DFDs can be extended to include environment and actor descriptions and interactions. They are a simple way to represent human-machine systems. No special tools needed (circles, arrows, and lines are enough).

And since all systems are embedded systems we can just add whatever descriptive information we care to. Maybe as annotations to systems boundaries. (just thinking off the top here)

item.title: Need to Weave the Stories Together
item.dc:creator: Tony
item.description:
Gene: I have significant experience as a Technical Writer. The questions that Technical Writer asks are “Who, What, When, Where, How, and Why”.

If you notice on my Powerpoint (at www.tonymar1556.wix.com/mysite) that I modify the Candy Store DFD’s from what is traditionally shown to include the Actor (the “Who”). In work projects, I often also edited in the “How” with a minor tweak. Standard DFDs, via their input/activity/output format, give the What, When, and Why.

That, in my experience, has always cover all the bases. Are you aware of other influences?
